Award.AwardTitle: Planning IUCRC at University of Pittsburgh: Center for Data Science for Materials Reliability and Degradation (MDS-Rely)
Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of Pittsburgh (Pitt) and Case Western Reserve University (CWRU) are planning to form a new IUCRC named the Center on Materials Data Science for Reliability and Degradation (MDS-Rely). The primary goal of MDS-Rely is to apply data science-informed research to better understand the reliability and lifetime of essential materials. This IUCRC builds on established centers at both locations focusing on Energy Materials, Advanced and Additive Manufacturing, and in Data Science and Analytics. Recent advances in materials data science have the potential to transform this field in creating new technologies that enable unprecedented lifetimes, durability in extreme environments, and understanding of various degradation and failure mechanisms. Our established relationships with industry and our multidisciplinary capabilities in protocols, modeling, and applications are key to taking on this grand challenge of long-lived technologies.

MDS-Rely will engage a diverse cohort of students, and develop broad data science capabilities to respond to employers' needs. MDS-Rely will harness relationships between industry and academia to make headways in applying data science to materials development, design, and reliability. MDS-Rely will include three Thrusts: (1) Enhanced Reliability Study Protocols, (2) Modeling & Service Life Prediction, and (3) Reliability and Degradation Applications. Thrust 1 will focus on designing data informed experimental studies of materials and developing a data science-based experimental design with both non-destructive and destructive evaluations to monitor material degradation. Thrust 2 will focus on degradation and reliability modeling of materials and will encompass graph-based network modeling, machine learning, image analysis, and time-series analysis. Data analytic pipelines will be created to inform future analysis. These models will give insight back to the design of data informed experimental studies. Finally, Thrust 3 will inform materials design choices for different stress conditions by understanding the main contributors of degradation in a material system. This will also allow for much more rapid material selection in the material choice portion of a system design. The workshop meetings further define specific projects to direct respond to industry needs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
• Project Outcomes Report

     

  • The IUCRC for Materials Reliability and Degradation (MDS-Rely) brought together administration, faculty, students, and entrepreneurs from the communities of Case Western Reserve University (CWRU) in Cleveland, OH and University of Pittsburgh (PITT) in Pittsburgh, PA.  

     

  • The MDS-Rely Planning Meeting was the major outcome of this project. The registration for the MDS-Rely Planning Meeting was available online at http://mds-rely.org/. More than 70 attendees participated in the MDS-Rely Planning Meeting, 37 of them represented industry, federal agencies and National labs. A few attendees obtained permission to access the meeting remotely in real time using Zoom video conferencing services. Significant help in preparation for the MDS-Rely Planning Meeting was received from the CWRU and PITT undergraduate students. They were involved in printing out and assembling the folders, preparing badges, and answering many questions from the MDS-Rely Planning Meeting attendees.

     

  • After attending the NSF Bootcamp in Virginia, conducting 117 discovery interviews with stakeholders from industry, federal agencies, and national labs, and hosting an extensive two day Planning Meeting; we have developed our vision, objective, and value proposition in concert with our future members.

     

  • Our Vision

     

  • MDS-Rely seeks to apply data science-informed research to better understand the reliability and lifetime performance of essential materials.

     

  • Our Objective

     

  • The goal of our center is to apply data science-informed research to better understand the reliability and performance lifetime of essential materials.  This important research topic has the potential to transform this field in creating new technologies that enable unprecedented lifetimes, durability in extreme environments, and understanding of various degradation and failure mechanisms.

     

  • Our Value Proposition

     

  • Industry 4.0 and the Digital Transformation is transforming industries

     

  • Reliability & lifetime performance of materials systems are key to their value
    • New technologies that enable unprecedented lifetimes & durability in extreme environments
    • Control and understanding of degradation and failure mechanisms and pathways

     

  • Data Science capabilities and tools are driving the Data Revolution
    • We will develop pre-competitive open source codes, algorithms and tools 
    • Universally applicable for developing their own next generation products

     

  • Human resources produced by MDS-Rely Center 
    • Data enabled employees essential to transformation; & in short supply 

     

  • Materials Data Science Training for companies
    • Prior to bi-annual MDS-Rely meetings

     

  • MDS-Rely Research Thrusts, Industry Sectors and Stakeholders

     

  • MDS-Rely Research Thrusts:
    • Reliability Study Protocols
      • Tools & Evaluations
    • Materials Data Science: 
      • Statistics, Machine & Deep Learning
    • Reliability and Durability Studies
      • Applications, Codes & Datasets

     

  • Industry Sectors: 
    • Coatings
    • Polymers
    • Metals
    • Building Materials
    • Automotive
    • Energy Systems
    • Aerospace
    • Lighting/Optics
    • Electrical Equipment
    • Marine
    • Biomedical Devices

     

  • Stakeholders:
    • Materials Researchers
    • Materials Suppliers
    • Component Makers
    • System Manufacturers
    • Asset Owners

     

  • Research Proposals

     

  • The following Research Project Proposals were presented at the MDS-Rely Planning Meeting in September 2019:

     

    1. Small Data & Early Indicators for Reliability Studies, Satish Iyengar
    2. Image Machine Learning for Reliability, Roger French
    3. Network Algorithms for Predictive Modeling of Photo-Voltaic Systems, Mehmet Koyuturk
    4. Optimization for Better Decision Making and Design, Oleg Prokopyev
    5. Reliability of Metallic Parts, John Lewandowski
    6. Time Series Analysis of Power Generating Systems in the Field, Mark DeGuire
    7. Image Machine Learning for Process Control, Jim McGuffin-Cawley
    8. Reliability of Binder Jet 3D Printed Inconel 625: Effect of Binder Burnout, Markus Chmielus
    9. Scratch Corrosion Study Protocol and Supervised Image Machine Learning, Jennifer Braid
    10. Service Lifetime of Polymers, Laura Bruckman
    11. Understanding Mechanical Abrasion Reliability of Multifunctional Coatings and Surfaces, Paul Leu
    12. Data Analytics for Benchmarking of Degradable Biopolymer Films and Tapes, Mostafa Bedewy

     

  • We will refine this list to include approximately 4-6 research projects at the launch of the center.
     

     

     

  • University of Pittsburgh Budget Summary:
  • Faculty Support:   $1,113.17
  • Fringe Benefits     $332.84
  • General Supplies   $1,100.11
  • Travel and Related   $5,728.83
  • Indirect Costs   $3,236.79
  • Total Expenses $14,940.62
     

     

     


Last Modified: 03/19/2020
Modified by: Paul W Leu
